Expectation1: Maintain regular communication with family members
Situation1: The grandmother learns that a family member is dealing with a significant personal crisis.
Expectation2: Stay updated on changes in laws and legal precedents.
Situation2: In the middle of jury instructions, your clerk hands you an alert that the Supreme Court has just issued a ruling that directly overturns the key precedent your current instructions are based on. You must stop immediately.
Story: As I stood at the bench, reading jury instructions, my phone buzzed in my pocket—a rare breach of protocol, but my clerk’s urgent face told me it was important. She handed me a note: the Supreme Court had just overturned the precedent at the heart of this case. My mind raced, trying to recall the details of the new ruling, knowing I had to halt proceedings and review the law immediately. At that moment, another message flashed on my phone’s screen: my daughter, frantic, saying my grandson was in crisis and needed me. My heart clenched. As a grandmother, I was expected to be present, to comfort, to call, to show my family they could rely on me. But as a judge, I was expected to remain impartial, to stay current with the law, to ensure justice was served without delay or distraction. The weight of both worlds pressed on me, each demanding my full attention, each unforgiving of neglect. I stood frozen, torn between the courtroom’s silent expectation and my family’s desperate need, unsure which duty I could bear to set aside.
